instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.TPS62180: What is TPS62180? This is a power chip responsible for many different power rails on 2016-2020 Macbook Pros,  most often known as the SSD buck converter chip responsible for NAND power rails.
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

Got this 15 Macbook which had liquid damage. Quite extensive around the <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>

After cleaning the area I have discovered that I get dead short 0.66Ohm on L9081 <SIGNAL>P2V5_SW2_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL>
The other output of <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> -  L9080 <SIGNAL>P2V5_SW1_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> is reporting 2.08 MOhm - 0.44 Diode. These measures are with removed L9080/1 coils

<SIGNAL>P2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is 1.30 Ohm

<CHIP>U9080</CHIP> is heating up, which perhaps is explained by the short.

I lifted up <RESISTOR>R5600</RESISTOR>, thinking it may be the only G3H feeding the <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>.
When lifted up, <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> heats up (up to 60*C) together with <CHIP>U8800</CHIP>/8700

Then, I lifted up <RESISTOR>R5620</RESISTOR> too and managed to get 20V 0.4A on the charger.

is this dead <CHIP>TPS62180</CHIP>? Or is there a possibility <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> to be busted too? Which doesn't seem to be available anywhere?

Regards



Seems like need to order it and wait 2 weeks, and was wondering if there anything else I can check before I fix this short?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message: Could not find this board schematic, but <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is close enough.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
You should change <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> first.

But I'm not sure what you mean with:
"L9080 <SIGNAL>P2V5_SW1_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> is reporting 2.08 MOhm - 0.44 Diode 
------------------------
<SIGNAL>P2V5_SW1_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> is 1.30 Ohm"

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
These long names are very confusing. Corrected it, I meant <SIGNAL>P2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is 1.30 Ohm. 
Thinking of the NANDs internal resistance. It is expected to be that low right?

I will order <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> then and will report once replaced. 

Thank you again.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Impossible to have 1.3 ohm at NAND power rail.
Apart of <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, something else is burnt there; NAND chip I think.
May be not worth to continue repairing this board...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Just received the <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> and replaced it.

It fires up to 20V/0.9A for a couple of minutes, then drops to 20V/0.5A. But <CHIP>U8800</CHIP> is heating up to over 100*C.

<SIGNAL>P2V5_SW1_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 0.93Ohm
<SIGNAL>P2V5_SW2_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 0.95Ohm

It seems like you were right, must be a shorted NAND. I assume we cannot disable a NAND?

[ATTACH type="full" alt="2020-08-29 10-42-16.JPG"]59390[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V on charger 0.4A - Short on <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>
threads.message:
You cannot disable any NAND.
If you have time to waste, try replacing shorted NAND with a chip from donor board, same model.
It has specific information, cannot be replaced with new.
